because we have all seen a beam of light being split into two beams of light and i will mute my phone because

the the sort of let's say i would say either logical or

interference is a common uh behavior that is exhibited by all kinds of waves including waves
on the surface of water right so two waves when they meet they can create a bigger wave or they can cancel each
other out and so effectively because of interference what happens is uh
light only travels towards detector number two so this is everything here has been known already in 19th century
so there's actually no quantum concepts that we have invoked yet and everything can be explained without any problems

the photon approaches the first beam splitter and at this point it sees that it can go this way and or that way and

and it goes this way and it goes this way right and then it goes this way from the

prescribes that the state of such system is described by a two-dimensional state vector okay
and quantum mechanics also tells us that information from quantum systems can only be extracted by the so-called

two-level quantum systems at least two special vectors that form the so-called measurement basis so whenever we were

measurement basis and the default measurement bases in quantum information theory and in
general in all implementations of quantum computers is the so-called z-basis and it consists of two vectors
very simple vectors one over zero and zero over one which can be used to map to a classical zero and a classical one
they are in short they are called cats so these symbols are called cats and cats are just a shorthand way to
indicate that these are vectors so we call them cat 0 and cat 1. and the default qubit state happens to
be cat 0. so whenever our program starts we know that it is in state cat 0 which really means it's in this vector state
and here's something fundamentally really really important right the the base is the two states uh that
are defined by the measurement basis or really by the observable are in principle the only things that are obser
that are possible that are possible to be observed in the measurement process so in other words there exists no objective reality right
so we cannot ask a quantum system what state you are in we can only ask uh
we can only ask are you excited zero are you kept one so we we say we have selected the z basis
for your measurement which consists of two special vector states k zero and kept one please tell me which of these
two states you are and that is why a system in a superposition ends up producing
at the end a random number upon measurement because it randomly chooses zero or one right it actually chooses k
zero and cat one but we map them to classical zero and classical one the problem is that the quantum system
may be in the state cat zero or it may be in the state cut one but it actually may be in the linear combination of both
of those states and that is expressed by a simple equation alpha k zero plus beta k one now consider when alpha is one and
beta is zero we have a state get zero if beta is 1 and alpha is 0 we have a state ket1 but if both of them are non-zero
then we have the so-called superposition and in fact there is no one single superposition there are infinitely many superpositions and we can draw this on
the circle this is not a perfect visualization by the way it should be actually drawn on the sphere but it
helps to sort of comprehend this better so we have a state cat 0 and state cat 1 which are vectors and these vectors are
linearly independent so there's 90 degree angle between them and really any state in between like this red ro for

and the quantum system might be in any of those states and if the system happens to be in the state get zero

probabilistic so we would say that the superposition state collapses to one of the observable states
and that is actually i mean it cannot be emphasized enough because it is a fundamental quantum doctrine
that a measurement of a quantum property does not reveal the value of this
property but instead the value of this property sort of comes into reality as a result
of the measurement right so in other words what we experience in
the world is sort of a projection onto the observable states only but the true nature of reality is sort of

we can we can add some mathematics to this now and the effectively
how we would represent the h transformation so when we take a default qubit state which is a cat 0 it is a vector 1 over 0
and the h transformation has the following matrix format in quantum mechanics
now every quantum transformation can actually be represented as a matrix because that is just in linear algebra
how we transform vectors right by multiplying them by uh by matrices and when we do this calculation we end up
with something like this and this is notice alpha and beta are both non-zero right and
what is more alpha and beta are actually equal to each other which tells us that
the resulting state is exactly in the middle between cat 0 and cat 1 which means there is a 50 probability of
observing a collapse to get 0 and 50 probability of observing or measuring a collapse to get 1. in other words that
is why we are able to use the h transformation in our random number generation because
it is a perfect quantum coin toss and even more amazingly if we
apply h twice in a row something interesting happens because when we multiply h by itself we end up with a
matrix that looks like this and this is the identity matrix and the identity matrix doesn't actually change the state
of a vector so in other words h is its own inverse so applying it once will create a superposition but applying it
the second time we actually undo the superposition and return the qubit or quantum system back into the original
state and that is why in in the earlier example when we had
when we had two h transformations applied in a row we ended up with a deterministic result
because the first beam splitter was creating a superposition the second one through the interference effect was
actually undoing it now the problem is of course how to interpret all of this and the
ontological character and the epistemological character of all of this is actually unclear and has been troubling physicists and philosophers
